title: List of United States Supreme Court cases, volume 136
text:
This is a list of the 36 cases reported in volume 136 of "<a href="United%20States%20Reports">United States Reports</a>", decided by the <a href="Supreme%20Court%20of%20the%20United%20States">Supreme Court of the United States</a> in 1890.
Justices of the Supreme Court at the time of volume 136 U.S..
The Supreme Court is established by <a href="Article%20Three%20of%20the%20United%20States%20Constitution">Article III, Section 1</a> of the <a href="Constitution%20of%20the%20United%20States">Constitution of the United States</a>, which says: "The judicial Power of the United States, shall be vested in one supreme Court . . .". The size of the Court is not specified; the Constitution leaves it to <a href="Congress%20of%20the%20United%20States">Congress</a> to set the number of justices. Under the <a href="Judiciary%20Act%20of%201789">Judiciary Act of 1789</a> Congress originally fixed the number of justices at six (one chief justice and five associate justices). Since 1789 Congress has varied the size of the Court from six to <a href="Seventh%20Circuit%20Act%20of%201807">seven</a>, <a href="Eighth%20and%20Ninth%20Circuits%20Act%20of%201837">nine</a>, <a href="Tenth%20Circuit%20Act%20of%201863">ten</a>, and back to <a href="Judiciary%20Act%20of%201869">nine</a> justices (always including one chief justice). 
When the cases in volume 136 U.S. were decided the Court comprised the following nine members:
Citation style.
Under the <a href="Judiciary%20Act%20of%201789">Judiciary Act of 1789</a> the federal court structure at the time comprised District Courts, which had general trial jurisdiction; Circuit Courts, which had mixed trial and appellate (from the US District Courts) jurisdiction; and the United States Supreme Court, which had appellate jurisdiction over the federal District and Circuit courts—and for certain issues over state courts. The Supreme Court also had limited <a href="Original%20jurisdiction">original jurisdiction</a> ("i.e.," in which cases could be filed directly with the Supreme Court without first having been heard by a lower federal or state court). There were one or more federal District Courts and/or Circuit Courts in each state, territory, or other geographical region.
<a href="Bluebook">Bluebook</a> citation style is used for case names, citations, and jurisdictions.
